citation.article-title: Two new genera of nocardioform actinomycetes; Amycolata gen. nov. and Amycolatopsis gen. nov.

p.s: Amycolata (A.my.co.lá ta. Gr. prefix a not; Gr. n. myces, fungus; L. ending ata of or pertaining to; Amycolata not having mycolates, α-branched, β-hydroxy long-chain fatty acids that are characteristic of members of the genera Mycobacterium, Nocardia, Rhodococcus, and Corynebacterium).
Actinomycetes forming branching vegetative hyphae with a diameter of 0.5 to 2.0 μm, which tend to break down into squarish subunits.
Aerial mycelium may or may not be present.
Aerial hyphae, when formed, may be sterile or may break down into chains of squarish to oval fragments or sporelike structures.
No endospores, sheaths, synnemata, sporangia, or sclerotia are present.
Not susceptible to phages specific for the Nocardia-Rhodococcus complex, Saccharomonospora, and Faenia.

Type IV cell wall composition (meso-diaminopimelic acid, glutamic acid, alanine, muramic acid, glucosamine, galactose, and arabinose); type A whole-cell sugar pattern (galactose and arabinose present; no madurose, fucose, or xylose; rhamnose variably present).

Type PIII phospholipid pattern (phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylmethylethanolamine present; phosphatidylinositol mannosides, phosphatidylinositol, and diphosphatidylglycerol variably present; phosphatidylethanolamine absent).
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA ranges from 68 to 72 mol%.
The type species is Amycolata autotrophica.
